We submit a draft of a Green Paper for presentation to Parliament.It sets out the Government's conclusions and proposals arising from the debate which the Prime Minister started with his Ruskin College speechlast October.2. The paper needs both to recognise the genuine achievements of the schools, often in face of great difficulties, and to assure a wider audiencethat legitimate criticisms are accepted and will be dealt with.3. It must also accept certain constraints. In particular -i. proposals must be compatible with our public expenditureplans;ii. it must respect the accepted division of responsibilitieswithin the education service if we are not to antagonise both the localauthorities and the teachers. The success of our efforts depends onthe co-operation of both.4. The draft illustrates at several points the limitations on policyimplied by divided responsibility for the system, including the absence ofany power to make selective grants. Consequently positive discriminationcan be advocated but Education Ministers can do little to ensure it.5. At their meeting on 15 June 1977 the Home and Social AffairsCommittee (HS) generally endorsed the scope and content of the draft and invited us to submit to the Cabinet a version revised further in the light ofthe points made in discussion. These points included the following -i. There should be a clearer affirmation of the Government'scommitment to comprehensive education. ii. There should be a stronger commitment to positivediscrimination in favour of special groups.iii. More should be said abouta. the changing role of women in society;b. provision for under-fives;c. the contribution of education to the Governmenfsindustrial strategy.6. We have consulted further with colleagues as invited by HS and haveembodied in tne attached draft amendments to take account of the discussion and of suggestions since made by colleagues. The appendix to thismemorandum draws attention to the principal passages involved. In generalthese can speak for themselves, but there is one matter which KS wished usto bring to the specific attention of the Cabinet. This is the question ofcounting members of ethnic minorities in the various sectors of education.It is dealt with in paragraph 97 of the draft but in terms which stop short ofa firm commitment. We see great difficulty in making a commitment in avery controversial matter just when we are entering into consultation witha very wide range of educational interests about it. and other related matters,but we consider it sensible to mention the Governmenfs concern.7. The Green Paper has to address itself both to the educational world and a wider public. Our consultations leave us reasonably confident of a sympathetic reception from the local authorities. There will be a mixedresponse from the teachers' associations. The National Association ofSchoolmasters/Union of Women Teachers will consider it does not go far enough; the National Union of Teachers is likely to be divided, but at the organisational level suspicious and defensive.8. Debate about education is never-ending. CONCLUSIONPROPOSALS AND RECOMMENDATIONSAPPENDICESEducation ExpenditureTeacher Number::Pupils per TeacherPupil Numbers166-168169-210A, BCDE FOREWORDby the Secretary of State for Education and science and the Secretary of State for WalesEducation in the last decade has undergone great changesin both size and structure. The speed and pace of thosechanges are remarkable. Twelve years ago, the labour government issued its first circular on comprehensivereorganization, an objective which is largely but not yetwholly achieved, and which the Government is determined tocomplete. Already in three quarters of our schools, the selective system is now a thing of the past. In 1973the school leaving age was raised to 16, following adecision also made by a Labour Government, in 1969.The content, as well as the structure, of education has changed. There has been a wide range of new demands onthe curriculum, the introduction of new methods of teaching, and the gradual acceptance of a new examination,the CSE. These changes have brought with them a gooddeal of controversy; controversy over what has been achieved, over standards, and over the aims educationought to have.The period of change coincided with a rapid expansionof the number of children in the schools, and of thenumber of young people in higher and further education.This in turn created a demand for many more teachers.Not surprisingly, both the turnover of teachers and theproportion of teachers with only a year or so of teachingexperience have been very high. And these factors - the speed of change, high turnover, inexperienced teacherstrying to cope with new demands and new methods - have put considerable strain on the schools. There are some areas of weakness in education and some unmet needs.This paper sets out proposals for dealing with them. None of this should mask the remarkable work being undertaken in many of our schools. It is the vigour,imagination and talent of the teachers in them thatimpress the visitor: schools that open their facilities and their resources for learning to the entire local community; schools that emphasize creativity in design,in making things as well as learning things; schoolsthat tackle with sustained enthusiasm the problems ofchildren from other cultures or speaking other languagesand make a little microcosm of a happy and co-operativeworld.We hope, therefore, that those who read this Green paper and note its recommendations will do so against this background of much that is exciting and even outstanding.So far as possible the Green Paper focuses on the educationnormally provided for children during their years of compulsory attendance at school. References are made tosome areas of special need, but it does not deal witheducation in special schools, or with further education;and there is only brief reference to nursery education.These important subjects are being dealt with in otherways. Some involve discussions with other Governmentdepartments.The proposals may be built upon, altered in the course ofdiscussion, or superseded by developments that will emerge'There can never be final answers nor an end to debate.But there are times for self-examination followed by the setting down of new objectives and new ways of reachingthose objectives. We believe we have now reached sucha time, and this Green Paper is a response to it. R&STRICTZDSUMMARYThis paper deals with the schools of England and Wales. Itconcentrates on the main stream of education from 5 to 16.During the past thirty years the schools have been understress because of population growth, wider social changes,and educational reorganisation. Pupil numbers are nowdeclining and will continue to do so for a decade at least.The schools will have; to work within tight expenditure limits for several years.We have more new school buildings and smaller classes than ever before. Great progress has been made in establishingcomprehensive secondary education and getting rid of the 11 plusexamination. The completion of this process remains a priority in education policy. Both primary and secondary schoolshave developed in the breadth and variety of the educationthey offer and their sensitivity to children's needs.Nevertheless there are many criticisms of the schools, from employers, parents, and others. They concern the standards of work achieved, particularly in certain key subjects likeEnglish, science, mathematics and modern languages, and, tosome extent, children's behaviour.Some of the criticisms commonly made are not well founded;there is no evidence of a general or widespread decline in standards of performance in schools. But others have some justification and must be taken seriously; among them is the gap between industry and the schools. Young people should reach maturity understanding our democratic society and its economic dependence on industry. The schools must measuretheir aims and achievements against society's growing needs.R&S7RIC7Q,' In a free and pluralist society there are bound to be many different views about the aims of education. But there isenough common ground in what most people want for their children to provide a basis for curricular planning.The allocation of responsibility at three different levels inthe educational system, between the school, the local educati011authority and the educational departments, is basically sound and does not need to be changed. But there is a need for more consultation and cooperation between the different levelsthan in the past on both the content of the curriculum andthe standards of performance achieved. The Green Paper sets out proposals for a review of the curriculum by localeducation authorities, as a first step towards establishingan agreed framework.Parents are playing an increasingly important part intheeducation system. They should be fully informed about the schools to which their children go, and encouraged toparticipate in their education. The report of the Committeeof Enquiry into the Management and Government of Schools,due to be published later this year, will deal in detail with the relationship between governing bodies and theirschools, the local education authorities, parents and thecommunity at large.The maintenance and development of the Welsh language gives rise to special needs in the schools in Wales.Effective methods of assessment must be developed and used at each of the three levels in the system, the school, thelocal education authority and thecountryat large. Goodrecords of the educational progress of individual children and special attention to the problems of transition fromschool to school are also essential. Positive policies are needed to meet the special needs ofcertain disadvantaged groups: ethnic minorities, travellers,the physically and mentally handicapped, and those sufferingfrom the effect of environmental deprivation. Teachersneed to be trained to serve in a multiracial and multiculturalcommunity.In the last resort, the quality of education depends on the teachers. It is more important than ever to attract goodrecruits to the profession and to improve the quality ofinitial and in-service training, and to increase opportunities for professional development.Schools serve the whole community and schooling is a preparatiofor the responsibilities of adult life. Schools should developcloser links with the community, with parents, with employersand trades unions. Closer understanding between schools andtrade and industry is vital to enable them to serve eachother and, in so doing, to contribute to the future prosperity of the whole nation. 1- In retrospect 1977 may be seen as a turning point in education. The school population is now at its peak; it willdecline for a decade at least;. The reorganisation of the secondary schools in England and Wales to eliminate selectionis largely accomplished. These two facts mark the end of aperiod in which the reorganisation of the school system andthe demands of growing pupil numbers have overshadowed alleducational debate and educational planning.2. Secondary education for all was introduced in 194-5*Since then the school leaving age has been raised twice,in 194-7 and 1972. Opportunities to move on to further and higher education have greatly increased:the proportion of young people benefiting from post-schooleducation has more than doubled since 1960. The developmentof the General Certificate of Education (GCE) and subsequentlyof the Certificate of Secondary Education (CSE) have provided a flexible system of examinations which four-fifths of allpupils now attempt. The changes in school leaving age,the growth of the relevant age group, and the increasein the proportion of those starting school before five andof those remaining at school after 16, have together led toan increase in the maintained school population of over 80% sinci3* Large scale expenditure by successive Governments wouldhave been needed merely to match this increase in the numberof pupils and to provide schools in new housing areas. Butin addition many old secondary schools have been rebuilt, theremaining all-age schools have been eliminated, and the quality of new school buildings has been greatly improved. Classsizes have been reduced. The minimum college of education coursehas been lengthened from two to three years and, with minorexceptions, professional training is now required for graduatesentering the teaching profession. Recruitment to the profession,already fully qualified,will soon become all-graduate. cooperation. Ideas about the reorganisation of schoolscontinue to evolve. The end of selection for secondary eduC9-5to which the Secretaries of State remain strongly committed^in sight. With the benefit now of substantial experience, -AEduCtime is ripe for a conference the Secretary of State for jand Science will organise later this year. This conferenceprovide an opportunity for sharing experience of successfulpractice in comprehensive schools.RESTRICTEDH. During the last ten years the schools system has changedradically. Secondary schools have been most affected, and about 80% of all secondary pupils are now in comprehensiveschools; but in many areas primary schools have also been involved. There have also been related changes in the quaii^-'of education provided by the schools. Primary schools have in recent years adopted methods and approaches to learningwhich reflect an improved understanding of children's growthdevelopment. Children have responded with interest and enth1151to an eyperience of learning going far beyond the oldelementary concept. The comprehensive secondary schools haveresponded imaginatively to the opportunities provided by theirbringing together pupils and teachers who would previously been kept apart. They have devised many new courses of studjto engage the interests and meet the needs of their varied Pu^and have led the way in the development of new systems ofpastoral care designed to ensure that children1s individualcircumstances are taken fully into account when decisions are taken about their educational programmes. Many of the sch00have placed a new emphasis on service to the local community'and have involved a wide range of boys and girls in social-other community work.5. The rapid development of comprehensive schools has ^eqgreat efforts by teachers, local education authorities a110-churches, and could not have been achieved without their ^ 6. During the last 30 years, the schools have felt the impact of massive social change. Britain has ceased to be the centre of an Empire, and has become instead a medium-sized european power with wide international connections and responsibilities.Many of the problems our country faces can only be resolvedinternationally; so we need to educate our children in anawareness of international interdependence, and in a sense ofinternational understanding. Our own society has alteredsubstantially, because of the large scale movement ofnew people into Britain, many of them from the Commonwealth.Ours is now a multiracial, multicultural country, and oureducation must reflect that too.7. The changes are not only in our relations to othercountries and other people. The development of newtechnologies makes some traditional skills obsolete,and demands understanding of new ones. Our population is both socially and geographically more mobile than before the war. All this requires us to educatechildren to be adaptable and resourceful. Yet the ways in which we teach, the discipline we employ andthe means of communication., have to take account ofthe earlier physical maturity of pupils, the socialtrends and influence of the media which together makeyoung people less willing to accept authority uncritically.RESTRICTED RBSIKICTFO8. These social trends have brought a new attitude towardsgirls and women, many of whom now expect to have jobs and bring up a family. The old division of labour between thesexes, and the educational stereotypes that went with it,are being challenged. The schools increasingly have toeducate both boys and girls not only for the world of work,but also for shared domestic responsibilities.I. RESPONSIBILITIES WITHIN THE EDUCATION SYSTEM9- The education system in this country is not, as is often ^assumed, run by the Education Departments alone. The EducatiActs divide responsibility among several partners. At thefirst level are the teachers, on whose relationship with individual pupils all learning depends. The teachers work ^within a framework set by the local education authority, w^xis represented in individual schools through the appointmentof governors and managers. The management and governmentmaintained primary and secondary schools in England and Walehas been under examination by the Committee of Enquiry undei^Mr P Taylor's chairmanship. The Committee's terms of refereinclude an examination of both the composition and functionj^of bodies of managers and governors, and also the relation between those bodies and local education authorities, schoolstaffs, parents and the local community. The Committeesreport has recently been submitted to the Secretary of St at and it is to be published later this year.10. The governors, in conjunction with the head teacher ^^his staff, are responsible for what goes on in the indivischool. At the second level is the local education auuuanswerable to its electorate and responsible for providingeducation within its area. Third, there are the Secretary ,nti011of State, responsible in law to Parliament for the promoting ^the education of the people of England and Wales. They 111 ^know what is being done by the local education authoritieS^through them, in the schools. In addition there are cer^matters, such as qualifications and superannuation arrant ^Consulwhere the Departments have a direct responsibility. abetween the Departments, the local education authorities' ^the teachers, is a vital element in the working of the esystem. II. RESOURCES11. In looking at the prospects for education we must avoid two traps. One is to ignore the need for economicrestraint which is necessary both to control inflation and to regenerate industry - the Government1s top twopriorities. The other is to assume that the difficultiesassociated with restraint make any improvement impossible.Although some improvements call for additional resourcesothers, including many of those proposed in this paper, do not,The extent to which increased resources for education willbe available in the future depends largely on the success ofthe Industrial Strategy. It is vital to Britain's economic recovery and standard of living that the performance of manufacturing industry is improved and that the whole range ofGovernment policies, including education, contributes as muchas possible to increasing industrial performance and therebythe national wealth.12. Although firm decisions on public expenditure havebeen taken for 1977-8, the figures for future years areprovisional and will be subject to review in the 1977 survey of public expenditure. The education budget increased very substantially between 1965/66 and 1975/6, by no less than60% in real terms. Between 1975/6 and 1977/8, education hasto take its share of public expenditure cuts amounting to 152 millions, a cut of 2.4%. Other programmes, such ashousing, roads and defence have also suffered reductions.It should, however, be possible to resume a modest rate of growth in public expenditure by the end of the decade. 13* The greatest strength of the schools lies in theirteachers. There are about 4-59*000 qualified teachers in maintained schools in England and Wales. This is50% more than in 1966, an increase achieved through a major expansion of training coupled with strenuous efforts to persuade former teachers to return to service.This additional teaching strength has been used toreduce class sizes substantially in the last ten years.In 1966 two-thirds of all primary school classes had more than 30 pupils, by 1976 the proportion had fallen to under half (45%). For secondary schools, theimprovement was from 27% in 1966 to 15%. Only onesecondary class in 4-0 now has 35 or more pupils, and only one in 100 has 35 or more pupils and is in thecharge of only one teacher.14-. In addition more teachers have been needed to dealwith a growing range of tasks outside the classroom.Apart from the duties carried by head teachers and those with special responsibilities, these tasks includecareers advice, pastoral work and home-school links.For this reason, average class-sizes are necessarilyhigher than the corresponding staffing ratios. Theseratios improved, between 1966 and 1976, from 28.0:1 to23.9:1 in primary schools, and from 18.4:1 to 17.0:1 in secondary schools - the best figures ever achieved.15. This rapid and sustained growth in the teacher forereflected the determination of successive governments toimprove staffing standards even when the school population was rising. By theearly 1970s, however, it became clear that the school population would not continue to rise as fast as had previously been forecast; a slower rate of growth inthe number of teachers designed to produce a total of510,000 teachers by 1981, was provided for in the white paper of 1972 (Cmnd 5174). For the last three years,RESTRICTED the continuing steep fall in projected births and the economicsituation have combined to reduce further projections of thenumber of teachers to be employed. The Governments expenditureplans, however, provide for sufficient resources to enablestaffing standards within the schools to be maintained attheir current levels, and additionally for a substantialexpansion of in-service training and induction in theperiod up to 1981. It will be the Government's aim to resume improvement of staffing standards within the schoolsas soon as economic conditions allow. These and othermatters related to the training and employment of teachersare discussed further in Section XI below.16. Teachers' and children1s performance are inevitablyaffected by their working conditions. The number and quality of non-teaching staff-schoolkeepers, laboratoryassistants and office staff; the school site and itssetting; the amount and distribution of teaching space,basic services, furnishing and equipment, and the provisionof specialised teaching areas all affect what schools can offer their pupils. A recent Government study,/shortly tobe published.7, which assessed the educational suitability ofthe stock of school buildings in England and Vales for thedemands of the next ten years, showed that about half the primary and nearly three-quarters of the secondary teachingaccommodation has been built since 19^-5. In general thefabric of permanent school buildings is in good condition and most schools are safe and healthy places. But,particularly in older schools, classroom and other accommodation can fall far short of today's standards.17- The number of school pupils is declining and will continueto do so for many years despite a projected upswing of the birth rate after 1978. Pupil numbers are expected to dropby more than a fifth between 1976 and 1989 - from 9.1 million in 1976 to 7.4 million by 1966 and to 7.1 million byThereafter a slow recovery to 8.1 million by 1996 is projectThe decline in numbers will reach the primary sectorfirst, falling from 5.2 million in 1974 to 3*8 million in 1986, while secondary numbers will peak at 4.1 million in 1979 and then fall to 2.8 million in 1991. Substantialbuilding resources will still be needed over the next10 years to provide for the movement of population from one area to another but the decline inpupil numbers should enable a substantial number of oldand inadequate school buildings to be taken out of use.Other surplus accommodation can be adapted to make good the inadequacies of buildings that will still be needed. But there will still be a backlog ofdesirable improvements which cannot be met in full.Priorities must be established between categories ofimprovement and the claims of areas and schools ofdifferent types; the inner cities (whose schools will benefit from the programme of capital expenditure announced by the Chancellor of the Exchequer in his Budget spee ch)and other deprived areas must be given full weight. the secretaries of State hope to announce their buildingpolicy for the next few years after there has been anopportunity for public discussion of this paper and ofthe school building study itself.16. As to the other running costs of the schools, which include items as diverse as expenditure on books and onschoolkeepers pay, it will not be possible for expenditure(in real terms) to rise as fast in the next few years asin the past. Non-teaching costs cannot be considered in isolation from teaching costs since the two interactclosely. The Government has given priority to employing teachers; accordinglyexpenditure restraints will fall more heavily oncapitation allowances and expenditure on heating, lightingcleaning and ancillary staff. Work is going on to secureRr.v-;selected RkSlKICikDthe best value for the money spent in this way.19. Everything that is said in subsequent sections must beseen against the background of the resources available.Each local education authority and each school has to assessits own capacity, in terms of qualified teachers, educationalequipment, accommodation and so forth, to achieve its objective;For instance, if a school wishes to offer a modern languageoption but has no qualified language teacher, it will be ableto achieve its wish only when that gap is filled. Resourceconstraints of this kind were not always taken into accountduring the period of rapid development in the curriculum andin teaching methods that occurred in the last decade, and theconsequences for the schools were serious. They must be borne in mind in any proposals for the future.III. CRITICISM AND DEBATE ABOUT THE SCHOOLS20. Much recent comment on education has been strongly criticalSome themes recur. Children's standards of performance intheir school work are said to have declined. The curriculum,it is argued, pays too little attention to the basic skills of reading, writing, and arithmetic, and is overloaded with fringesubjects. Teachers are said to lack adequate professional skillsand not to know how to discipline children or to instil in themconcern for hard work or good manners. And underlying all thisis the feeling that the educational system is out of touch withthe fundamental need for Britain to survive in a highlycompetitive world through the efficiency of its own industryand commerce. Boys and girls, it is said, are not equipped to earn their own living, and do not understand how vital it isthat they contribute to the future prosperity of the country.21. Some of these criticisms are true. There is a wide gap between the world of education and the world of work. Boysf-ind girls are not sufficiently aware of the importance ofindustry to our society, and they are not taught much about it.R STR!CTm In some schools, the curriculum has been overloaded, so thatthe basic skills of literacy and numeracy, the building blocks*i cof education, have been neglected. A small minority of schoolhas simply failed to provide an adequate education by modernstandards. More frequently, schools have been over-ambitiousiintroducing modern languages without sufficient staff to meetthe needs of a much wider range of pupils, or embarking on nevmathematics without making sure the teachers understood whatthey were teaching, or whether it was appropriate to the pup1capacities or the needs of their future employers.22. Other criticisms are misplaced. They assume uniformlyhigh standards in the past from which we have fallen. Yetof the two million illiterate or semi-illiterate adults in britain today, many were educated before comprehensive schooor modern methods were ever heard of. Recent studies haveshown clearly that today's schoolchildren read better thanthose of thirty years ago. School curricula are moreambitious than they were: far more children, over a wider range of ability, study a modern language or science thandid a.-generation ago. And far more proceed to full-timehigher education. This means that employers recruitingschool-leavers or A level leavers are looking at a much more heavily 'creamed' group of young people than their predecesa decade or more ago.23. The picture, then, is far from clear. Much has been achieved: but there is legitimate ground for criticism andconcern. Since education, like any other public service, lSanswerable to the society which it serves and which pays -orthese criticisms must be given a fair hearing.24. It was against this background that the Prime Ministercalled in his speech at Ruskin College, Oxford on 18 October4- to last for a public debate on education. The debate was no^ be confined to those professionally concerned with education,but was to give full opportunity for employers and trades unions,and parents, as well as teachers and administrators, to make their views known. In the autumn of 1976 Ministers held aseries of meetings with national organisations representingamong others teachers, parents, local authorities, teacher training institutions,RESTRICTED education officers and advisers, the Schools Council andthe churches. Then in the opening months of this yeara series of regional conferences was held, seven in Englandand one in Wales, with invitations issued to local authoritieSin each region, to teachers, employers, trade unions, the churches, parents and students as well as other individuals and organisations with a special concern with education.In this setting many valuable ideas were put forward, both at the conferences themselves and in written documents.After that, a further round of meetings was held withthose consulted the previous autumn. This process identifie^a substantial measure of agreement on the direction in whichwe need to look for improvement in the schools.IV. AIMS AND WORK OF THE SCHOOLSA. General aims25. Education necessarily assumes certain values;a complex and diverse society, as Britain is today,includes groups committed to many different systems ofvalues. So if we are to agree as a community on oureducational aims, they must be simple andfirmly founded on the individual concern which parentswant the education service to have for their children. The majority of people woiild probably agree withthe following attempt to set out these aims, though theymight differ in the emphasis they would placeon one or the other :i. To help children develop lively, enquiring minds,the ability to question and to argue rationally'and to apply themselves to tasks;ii. To instil respect for moral values, for other ^people and for oneself and tolerance of other ^a^Slife;To understand the world in which we live, andinterdependence of nations; &S5TSIC7IDVI.vii,To help children to use language effectively andimaginatively in reading, writing and speaking;To help children to appreciate how the nation earnsand maintains its standard of living and properlyto esteem the essential role of industry and commercein this process;To provide a basis of mathematical, scientific andtechnical knowledge, enabling boys and girls to learn the essential skills needed in a fast changingworld of work;To teach children about human achievement and aspiratiin the arts and sciences, in religion, and in the search for a more just social order.26. Most schools would find little difficulty in subscribing tthese common aims as a framework for the exercise of teachers'professional skills and judgement. But they are bound totranslate them differently into classroom practice since theymust take account of local circumstances, the teachers' knowledgeof their pupils, and available resources. Some aims vary in importance at different periods of a pupil1s education; others are constant throughout. All these aims apply to both boys and girls. Equal opportunity does not necessarily mean identicalclassroom provision for boys and girls but it is essential that,in translating their aims into day-to-day practice, schoolsshould not by their assumptions, decisions or choice of"teaching materials limit the educational opportunities offered to girls.B. The work of nursery and primary schools2?. Entry to nursery or primary school is an important event.For many children it may be their first big experience of lifeaway from the family. More than half our children now start"their schooling before they are five in nursery schools andclasses, or in the reception classes of primary schools. In the last few years there has been a big expansion of nursery education, mainly on a part-time basis; and as the age groupsdecline the proportion of under-fives who are in school will rise steadily, even though limitations on resources willconfine further expansion of provision in the immediate future to the areas of greatest social deprivation.28. Nursery education is valuable for almost all children.But it should supplement, not replace, what a child learns a*home. The experience of the playgroup movement has shown thatparents often wish to be closely involved in the education anddevelopment of other young children as well as their own; and professional guidance parents can play a valuable part in nursschools and playgroups and by so doing can come better to ful^their own role as parents. The Government has in recent year3encouraged local authorities to improve the coordination ofall available services for under-fives so as to make themaximum use of existing resources in the education, social services and health fields, as well as those which the commim1can provide through volunteers and voluntary bodies. This Isan area of provision in which there is a growing interest,especially in relation to the needs of children with backgro^of disadvantage of various kinds, and in which a number of ^eideas are being tried and tested. The Department of Educati011and Science and the Department of Health and Social Securityhope shortly to issue a further joint circular to localauthorities on this matter.29. By five years of age most children have acquired aconsiderable degree of physical co-ordination, and all buta few are able to use and to make themselves understood in ^everyday language. But even by that age children are notice3different from each other in emotional and social maturity^in achievement and in what interests them. The differencesbecome more marked as the children grow older. Over the yea?3'primary school teachers have become increasingly conscious 0the need to cater for the individual characteristics of chi-1-RKTrjCTFD and more adept at doing so. But at the same time childrenhave to learn to work together so that they may develop thesocial skills, concepts and attitudes necessary to membership of the school and the wider community. Religious education,the one compulsory subject, has an important part to play inthis,30. Primary schools have a special responsibility for improvinchildren's powers of language, particularly their capacity to read and write. Since 1948 standards of reading, as measured in a series of national surveys, have gone up but more needs to be done and can be, if teachers are givenenough help.
